comment: Whether you actually help fund this, you promote this, or you just watch, thank you. And a BIG NOTE: This is a massive experiment we are undergoing in public, so if there are new features, other offerings, new tiers, or anything you think would be awesome for us to embrace, feel free to throw them out to me. A big part of this movement is a focus on collaboration and embracing our little community. This is the first step into the great unknown. :)

First, congratulations for pulling off the nearly impossible by retaining your name and brand! I know that's not easily accomplished in a situation like this. Phil, since you have the following you do, how does using patreon benefit you and your organization?  I'd have allot more faith in your network remaining impartial if you simply accepted support through your own merchant account through your own website, instead of placing another biased, corporate influencer in between your financial supporters and your organization. Seriously, I do need that to be explained, because Patreon is just another corporate roadblock that uses your money and attempts to control your narratives by threatening to ban you if you report things in a way that they don't like. It's already started happening to others. Using Patreon makes me wonder why, since, at your level, you'll obviously be generating more traffic for patreon that patreon will ever generate for you.

I like your content, and I think this is a good idea, but there are problems with doing the news as you want to do it. The problem isn't getting the facts right, or even you giving your opinion once the facts are right. The problem is how you are painted by competitors, commenters, or critics. Rachel Maddow does very deep dives into the subjects she covers, and always throws in little quips about how she feels, and while we might say she is objectively analyzing the facts, someone who disagrees will always accuse her, and you, of bias. If you think Trump's healthcare plan is bad because the CBO predicted millions will lose healthcare, that's great, I agree, but someone who disagrees is always ready to call you a biased liberal, and the attack the facts you present. It works the other way too, gun regulation is more complicated and nuanced than one might think, and there are good arguments on both sides, but people don't let the facts change them, they get more entrenched in their views. Even if you don't give your opinion, and just give the facts, if the facts skew towards one side of an argument, you will be seen as a representative of that argument. I laud your efforts, and if anyone can do this it's you, but this is an issue you have to consciously tackle, or else you'll be painted the same color as every other news show out there that just set out to do the news.

Phil, I've been watching your videos religiously on YouTube and Facebook since roughly 2009 (or whenever it was you started vloggity I think), and no matter what topic you're talking about I've always admired your openness to other opinions and willingness to change your own. Philip DeFranco  From a fan; someone who has connected with many of your videos throughout the years, I urge you to consider this. Granted, I am no businessman. I am not savvy in marketing either. However, I am a fan. I connected, much like many others out there, with your old channel: SourceFed. Honestly, the comedic value within it has changed my life, especially when times grew very dark. The channel inspired creativity and gave a warm home-like feeling to all who chose to join in and watch. The fiasco that's happened recently with the Nerd channel has caused chaos and uprising within the audience and even some previous hosts, causing them to speak their minds.   There is SO much potential with the ideology of SourceFed, and it can be resurrected. It just needs the guidance and loyalty to achieve said potential. I plead for you to reconsider, especially with your new move to be an independent creator, yet again. You know what works; your 5.4 million subscribers is a small testament to that. You're superb at finding loopholes and finding the advantageous route through anything you do. Here's what I'm thinking:  Merge the SourceFed component with what you're doing and you'll have such a spring board in what you're doing. You have your comedic side and also a news network that shows you, the audience, what the real news is. By bringing in the cast and crew from the SourceFed team, you bring that fanbase, which is amazingly large considering all that has been done by them. By gathering the lost sheep of SourceFed and putting them in mixed in with your ideas about real news, real talk, real everything,... Now That is something I feel we all would watch.   I know you're a busy guy. I know that there's probably a one in a million chance you'll see this (and another one in a million you'll respond). However, I believe in trying to put whatever I can out there to make a difference; a change for the better. I hope you can hear my voice. I hope you see what I see, and see what we love. It's a cry for help from someone who can't do much about what has happened. Regardless of your decision, you still have my sub. You're a great person and have such a talent for what you do. I just implore you to hear me and the cries of many people who want to see justice for the people we've supported for so long. I appreciate your time and patience. Stay classy, ya beautiful bastard!

It's hilarious the amount of "He's a Millionaire" comments I see. My response is, proof? What you saw an article about how his worth is X amount? Well, if you look up Jerma985's net worth (popular twitch streamer) first result claims he's with 100 billion. And hey, for another quick comparison:  1. Site claims that Phill's net worth is 4 Million. 2. Another site claims the Game Grumps net worth is 2.4 Million.  Phill has 5.3 Mil subscribers. Grumps have 3.8 Phill has 1.8 Billion video views. Grumps have 3.1 Billion video views.  Phill puts out 1 video a day, while grumps put out 2-3 a day.  They both sell shirts, grumps are more seasonal, limited time offers,  and as a result they amass a shit-tonne of sales Phills are daily and  are often re-prints of existing ones, meaning less will be sold with  each subsequent sale.  If you were to base their worth off of youtube, the thing they're famous for, the grumps would earn alot more than Phil simply because of the amount of views they're charting, about 70-80% more than Phill's, and yet, there they sit at 1.6 million less in worth to Phil. I have such a massive problem with the haters in the comment sections. Mainly because they embody everything that Phil stands against, which is misinformation and ignorance.  I'm not sure if people are aware, but YouTube creators, even extremely successful ones, are NOT all millionaires despite what clickbaity internet articles lead you to believe.   Second, the reason he's asking for money isn't because he's a "greedy fuck" etc. but because he's trying to provide advertiser FREE content. He's giving you news for free if you become a supporter or not. Can you say the same about the cable subscription you pay for to watch CNN and other news sources of the like? I really don't think so.  Although it makes me so happy to see the overwhelming support, every single person that says something about Phil's greediness is entirely missing the point of why he's crowdfunding and are the kinds of people that shouldn't be in his audience anyway.  I've been a fan for around 8 years now and hope he will thrive and be my favorite news channel long after I graduate University. His network will be the future of news, and I'm so excited to see how it grows from here.

Ok if you so ardently believe that I want you to prove beyond reasonable doubt that he is a millionaire. What is this standard you ask? This means that the proposition being presented by the you must be proven to the extent that there could be no "reasonable doubt" in the mind of a "reasonable person" that Phillip deFranco is a millionaire. There can still be a doubt, but only to the extent that it would not affect a reasonable person's belief regarding whether or not the Phil is a millionaire. Also your burden of proof is to be such that the facts you provide must exclude to a moral certainty every reasonable hypothesis or inference other than his being a millionaire. What is a reasonable person you ask? A reasonable person refers to an ordinary person who exercises care while avoiding extremes of boldness and carefulness. I disagree that your claim against his supposed wealth is irrelevant to his crowdfunding goal. He is crowdfunding because he isn't wealthy. Do I believe that you will actually take the time to prove your point? No, because your just a troll looking to get a rise out of people in an angry fashion. Trolls don't do well against well formulated, judicious opposition because it's no longer "fun." A) He's had to purchase and remodel commercial properties, as well as furnish them and provide work computers and server equipment, which are all fairly expensive things to do. B) You don't invest all of your income into an unproven startup, even if you're a millionaire. Ever heard the saying "Don't put all your eggs in one basket"? C) He's essentially asking for interested parties to invest in his startup. Elon musk is a Billionaire, yet he still gets investors from interested parties every time he starts a new business because having other creative minds and allies is good. This will help Philip to understand the demands of consumers, as well as somewhat allowing the consumer base to have a say in what is going on with his channel. Good things. D) He is offering some nice things to people who pay. He's not begging for money, he's simply saying "Hey, here's an unbiased way to donate to the project, get some cool perks, have a say in the development of the project, and all in all help expand my business to be more entertaining for you guys" and nobody is obligated, you can donate if you want to, and are capable of, donating, or not. Its up to you. Essentially, running businesses requires a boatload of capital and the ability to pay for employees, equipment, etc. He also wants to keep his news as unbiased as possible, so he's not getting large investors or large advertisers involved because they tend to meddle.

You do realize that this is how YouTube works right? The majority of YouTubers can't even live off of the ad revenue they make from posting videos. This can also be because most people probably either skip ads or block them through AdBlocker. Most of the money for successful YouTubers come from fans who support them through donations and patreons like us. This way all fans can chose how much they want to pay for the content that they are getting rather than having to pay a subscription fee. Its a way to support the content creators based on what they create so that way we only pay what we feel is worthy of our hard earned cash. This is also a way for everyone to be able to view the content for free that is being distributed, meaning you don't have to pay if you don't want to but still are able to enjoy the content just the same.

That Weird Otaku Girl - Kadel I get that he wants more money yes. I don't agree that he can't live off of the ad revenue or there wouldn't be ads. Companies wouldn't fund him or pay him to run ads if nobody was watching them. Also If we're paying for it how is it free? As I said in another post, it's like the NFL owner asking the tax payers to pay for his new stadium.

But the content is free..... I mean you're watching him now aren't you? The only reason why some people choose to pay is because they feel obligated to support him and respect the content he creates. Think of it like how a street performer earns money. They go out of their way to create a performance for onlookers lurking in the streets. If an audience member feels satisfied with the performance, they'll be willing to give a couple dollars or some spare change to the person who had just preformed. This doesn't mean that everyone gives them their money, but only those that feel obligated to out of respect to the performer. Its the same way with Philip DeFranco and other YouTubers. You want to help support them and continue creating the content you like and enjoy. If you don't want to support Philip DeFranco with your money, that is totally fine, I respect that since I know not everyone has the money to support the creators they like. A way to help support your favorite content creators is to subscribe to their channels, watch their videos, hit the like button, and just comment about how you enjoy their content with a positive and respectful out look instead of a negative one that only discourages their content and them selfs.

Richard Henderson  you're saying I don't get a return, but I'm TELLING you I do. Patreon allows for Phil to create pay-walled content that I want access to. So there's my actual concrete return. Also what I'm trying to explain is that the content he would "create anyway" won't exist without some kind of sponsorship. He would keep making videos I'm sure, but of the same caliber? As frequently? As freely? Unlikely. I want the most free, frequent, and professional videos possible from him. I'm investing in that outcome.   It's also not at all like an NFL owner having taxpayer dollars build a stadium?? Taxpayers have no choice in paying taxes without facing legal repercussions, in that instance the best they could do would be to try to vote representatives out of office in the next election. Which would probably be too late to change where the money goes. Patreon is a fully opt-in program that allows me to choose how much I want to pay and I can cancel at any time if I feel I no longer want to support the endeavor.   I'd also like to address the issue of self investing that people seem to be bringing up a lot. The problem with a single person personally bank rolling a project that probably costs upwards of a quarter million dollars a year (five full time employees and studio space in LA?? That's not a crazy number right??) is that it's totally unsustainable. It eventually has to turn a profit or the investor runs out of money. Phil has said many many times that ads from YouTube do not and will never cover the expenses of the show. His videos are consistently demonetized for featuring sensitive or adult content, he cannot access the highest pay scales (that are open to all advertisers) because he hasn't made a kid friendly video in his life. So. If not from YouTube ads, then he has to make a profit some other way. I would prefer to pay my $1 than deal with in show ads or pandering to get more Adsense. With enough crowd funding I would like to see Phil remove all pre-roll ads as well, or as much as he is able. He had also said (in this video as well as others) that he has personally invested a significant amount of money into this project. I would bet he personally bought out his contracts, leased studio space, and covered the cost of transition. Ideally he will be using Patreon money to hire more staff and handle upkeep.   If in a few months time I find no improvement in show quality, quantity, or ad free news, or if I feel the Patreon exclusive rewards are not up to par, I'll likely cancel my Patreon subscription, because I will not feel like I'm getting the returns I was promised.   I am trusting Phil to not sell out his channel, I'm trusting him to deliver on promises made in this video. In the same way I would have to trust anyone I pay to perform a service well. If he fails, he'll lose my investment, however minimal that may be. The value of crowdfunding for someone like Phil as opposed to an investment group or advertisers is that he can count on people coming and going at their leisure without it significantly impacting his funding simply due to the sheer volume, unless he truly fails to deliver.

Richard Henderson ok now I'm confused too. So you don't have a problem with him using Patreon to create funds for his news show? And your only problem is with him telling his fans about the new project (the new project IS his Patreon page)? Like genuinely have you used Patreon before? Because that might be the one thing we really aren't seeing eye to eye on with this, you seem to just not really know how it works like as a tool, which he definitely didn't explain in the video I think he just assumed people would be familiar. So Patreon isn't a social media site, it also isn't really a crowd funding site like indie gogo or something. You set up a page that people can pay either by month or by "creation" (that's usually more for artists or comics coming out with new issues) for access to exclusive content. Different donation tiers would allow you access to different exclusive content ($1/month for behind the scenes videos, $5/month for Q&A videos, $10/month for a unique Polaroid mailed to your address with a thank you on the first of each month; these are not Phils perks but examples of ones I've seen or received). So I /am/ paying for content that is not freely available to everyone on the internet. There's that point sorted. The other thing is that Patreon is really ONLY used for this service, so he didn't have a Patreon "following" before this announcement. To me he's not asking us to donate, he's just clueing us viewers in to a new platform he'll be putting content out on and the changes we can expect in his usual show. My two cents.  Is the new business model not involve posting to YT anymore? I wasn't clear what your plans were. But without consistently posting "free" content, your patreon base will start to drop off over time. And the revenue. You still need to actively recruit new supporters. I only say this because of a lack of real content these last two days.  Personally, I thought your news network plans would be more than just a patreon page. I realize so many creators spend a lot of time on their content, I just can't financially support every single one. And while I like where this channel evolved from (no more "babe" thumbnails - yikes!), it's quality and content choices have never even come close to filling me in on real news. It's always been a mix of news with some internet controversy that I find to be more of a guilty pleasure. I subscribe to HBO now largely because I love the Vice content. I just don't feel like your content warrants a minimum of $5 a month, especially when you have such a large fanbase already. Personally the content just isn't there. For my contribution, I need a cheaper minimum or higher quality content.  To be frank, there is SO much digital content out there, creators have to compete now more than ever. While I don't plan to follow you to patreon in the near future, I still wish you luck.

You cannot make an unbiased or balanced source, it is humanly impossible. Even if you didn't draw any conclusions and just presented evidence you'd still be introducing bias. This can range from what evidence you decided to show (as there will be times where you can't show all of it), to the order in which you show it, and even the minute tones you use to present evidence can and will introduce bias. So do not say you are making a bias free perfectly balanced show, because you are not and cannot. You're best goal would be to try and make a show with as little bias as humanly bias.

edgeninja I can see you're point. You don't want Phil to become "serious" when talking about the news, instead of entertaining as he is now. But I'd contest, by the very definition, Phil is a journalist because he writes and prepares news commentary that's is broadcasted to an audience. As long as his delivery remains the same, I don't personally see the issue. Also, Ronald Reagan was also an entertainer/actor before he was President in the 80's and is universally admired by all party lines. Don't judge those making the jump by current people in said offices, aka Trump.
Implying journalists aren't entertainers.
edgeninja as long as he isnt a person that cherry pick the facts because he has an agenda,  but considerind a lot of these youtubers lean right im sure he will.
"Reagan is universally admired" is a stretch. I think he was a godawful president, personally.

Thing is, "commentary" isn't the same as news reporting. I could start a vlog tomorrow and give my two cents on the issues of the day. That wouldn't make me a journalist. Not trying to hate on Phil in the least. The man deserves heaps of praise for all the blood, sweat, and tears he's shed to build what he has. I just think he doesn't know what he's getting himself into.

There's such a huge cult of personality surrounding Reagan that few Americans realize it, but you can almost draw a straight line between him and Trump. Reagan's the guy who started the whole de-regulation of Wall Street/the Big Banks that continued through proceeding administrations. He began the trend of union-busting, shipping jobs overseas, supply-side economics (taking money from the poor to give to the rich). And, of course, he was propelled to the White House through the rise of the radical religious right, which also got Trump elected.

I'm trying to make sense of your logic and it's not coming to me at all. Putting the classification of "entertainer" on Phil has little to do with his qualifications or reasons to start this news network. Did you watch the whole video? He's trying to make a platform in which real, important conversations can be had by people with opposing views. Too often we see each other in the light of the extreme. Idealist or not, someone needs to be a voice of reason, and I don't understand why you think Phil shouldn't be trying to bring in that voice. No big news network is going to do this in his place. Making the Trump comparison seems completely unreasonable; there are no other points than the title you've given Phil as an entertainer to connect your argument that Phil's news network will bring about something related to Trump becoming president. I want to hear your thoughts on that. Particularly why you consider him an entertainer when his channel is mostly dedicated to sharing news in the most non-biased way he can, and why it's such a bad decision.

Not just ask other people to do it for you so you have zero risk, and then if you fail at it it's OTHER people that have to pay for your mistake instead of you. Phil, I like the concept and agree with much of what you espouse, however I think you need to become a bit more objective to create the news network you're attempting to build. You have a tendency to lean to the left on certain subjects; most of the statistics you cite when you report the news lean to the left. I understand most of the statistics are generated by the left however statistics shouldn't be right or left and when they are they shouldn't be reported (or you need to take more of a centrist view noting this)! Perhaps your show needs a mathematician who can tell you when source, sample pool size, distribution of sampling, etc are invalid. I'm an active viewer, however I don't comment often. I don't feel like the viewpoints I have are any more valid than others (having not lived their lives from their point of view). My political views are quite centrist, and I rarely comment because I'm worried I may accidentally offend someone. Political correctness is a minefield these days. I hope your network starts to report more on the polarization of society. You need to take more of a breakfast club approach. Labels are dangerous; often empowering people to act in stereotypically labelled ways. We're all humans we need to drop the labels and see ourselves as such. Defranco Nation, lets try Human Nation!

To those calling this a money grab =  Phil has always stated that he wanted to show unbiased news, that real research should be done in journalism and that his videos here are a 'conversation' - you have people from all kinds of backgrounds watching this show.  He has been with Discovery and such for 4 years and if he felt the need to leave them to create this news network, that suggests that he couldn't do the true unbiased network he wanted to create with them.  Making that decision to leave their funding and that security is a giant risk for his entire career, but he still choose to do it for the principle of what he's trying to achieve.  Now yes, Phils made a lot of money on youtube over the years, he has a nice house and his wife doesn't have to work - he clearly has sensible finances personally. But this show already has quite of few members of staff, it requires a premises. Discovery were clearly footing the bill for a lot of those business expenses that Phil is now trying to do off his own back. He may have a lot of money for one individual - but he's talking about hiring full time employees, operating and paying rent on a space, investing in equipment and research and lord knows what else - most of which were things he didnt have to fund individually. He has already stated he's investing his own money into this - I truly believe Phil wouldn't ask for funding if he basically was able to do without it.  If you are a fan of phil, if you believe that this truly is a 'conversation' and you support the idea of bias free well researched journalism, then you shouldn't begrudge him for asking for support. a whole news network is not something one man can achieve off his own finances, even if he is pretty minted from youtube money.  Not to mention - he's had so much demonetization lately and youtube is an incredibly unpredictable and unreliable platform for creators now - that money has probably decreased while his actual subscribers and views have increased.   He's asking the people who care enough about the show to pay forward their support, for the show to continue to exist and thrive.   I think what Phil is trying to do is huge - potentially unattainable - but I am perfectly happy to part with 5 bucks a month to watch him try. The last few years have shown the true dangers of the media, and the importance of transparency - The fact that someone is risking their career to try and tackle that in any small way is just incredibly impressive and noble.   TL/DR  Don't be a dick, understand that Phil is trying to do something good, and he doesn't have money coming out of his ass. If you want to support him great, if you don't you know where the door is. simple.

I implore you to re-watch the video and really listen to what he's saying. He just said that he left his parent company, and personally invested his own money to buy back every single one of his franchises from said parent company. That likely put a severe dent in his bank account, as these were not small channels.  Then, if you've been watching any of his recent videos that talk about YouTube, you would know that a very large portion of his videos are being demonetized under the new regulations, and those that aren't are usually under certain flags that mean they will make much less than they could. Since he is no longer with a network, he is not guaranteed certain kinds of money anymore, he is solely at the whim of what YouTube ad revenue makes, which right now, with what's been going on, he is not set up to do.   A patreon would mean that, regardless of how bad the YouTube ad revenue debacle turns out for his company, the fans who watch will still be the ones that his companies revenue comes from, allowing this endeavor to be as unbiased as they can make it. Being with just about any corporation like they had previously will come with some sort of leaning agenda, however small.

Those complaining and that he's panhandling on YouTube are dumb. He may have 5m subs but if you've been watching his channel even within the last year you've realized that YouTube does not give him top tier ad revenue. His videos are also blocked under the restricted mode, further diminishing the returns via ad revenue. Creating a new networks, paying for utilities, staff, etc. is very expensive. Ad revenue alone (considering how big companies are pulling ads off of YouTube and forcing them to be more restrictive to who gets top tier ad revenue) would not be possible or sustainable. He's taking a risk and is investing his own money into this. He could have stayed safe and under his contract but he would have a lot more restrictions to what he can say and what he can upload. Under the circumstances of how YouTube demonetized many videos that they consider not ad friendly, it most likely created more content restrictions for Phil. I've been watching him since nearly the beginning of his YouTube career and he's definitely a guy I would trust. I'm not saying everyone should. But he's forsure one of my favourite if not my favourite content creator on this platform. Many creators on  YouTube are supported by Patreon. SciShow with the Green Brothers have been supported by Patreon for years now. If you don't like it, don't donate. But don't spread hate.

I don't blame anyone for being sceptical, it's the internet and in the end he's a stranger.   He mentions in the video that he's putting his own money in to this. Of course, we have to take his word for that. Personally, I do believe him, but I can completely understand the doubt.  I don't think it's realistic to expect someone to start a news network or any large network for that matter, with only their own money. How much is really a few million dollars in the attempt to start something like this? I don't think it's viable to say "I'm starting this with my own money" as if that would never could potentially change or as if he could cover that to begin with.  Nothing is stopping him from using the current formula, but looking at the bigger picture it's fair to say that he's not reaching that many people. How many views does a single show get? About 3 million? He's probably trying to reach a much larger amount of people than that. I can imagine that the end goal is hundreds of millions.  I think he's genuinely going for it and speaking the truth. I completely see where you are coming from and understand what you are saying though. Be sceptical, don't put your money in something you don't trust or at least understand that when you do, you will not gain anything out of it.  Only time will tell!

To anyone saying "Phil is rich anyways, why's he asking us for money":   Did you consider that he had to buy back the rights to his show from Discovery (which I imagine was much more than just a couple thousand dollars)? He had to pay for this, for his own studio (he can't use Discovery's anymore) and the work it needed, to pay his staff (Discovery is no longer around to do this), and his own equipment (he can't really use Discovery's anymore).   Anyone who's watched Phil for any more than a couple of months should be able to see that he isn't trying to con us out of extra money or anything.  He's asking for our support as he takes a huge risk. You aren't forced to help him. But doing so makes it easier for him and less of a risk.

Don't know if you read these.   I used to watch your videos 5 years ago, don't remember why i stopped. Back then i could watch anything entertaining, but now i only care about keeping informed on news that effects me.   If you want to stay true to your promise to lead with the facts you have my support and the support of people like me. i desperately desire for a modern Walter Cronkite or someone i know i can trust.   I DON'T want someone who wants to flush out a new "political" video every day or talks to people on the street for pageviews (anyone can do that). if you do decide to saturate your videos with entertainment for the monetization, just make sure to hold a respectable/well-researched segment once or twice a week. (Please, always present both sides of the argument like you plan to, and provide sources other than reddit).  Personally,  i don't care for multiple personalities. i would only prefer one anchor (you) with correspondents, the way John Stewart did it.   Modern news networks are failing, but they belong to corporations that are too big to fail. those guys are your competition and they don't want you to succeed.   Keep your target audience above 20. Your viewers may have started out as kids, but they are growing up and getting jobs and looking for someone to act as their voice in society.  i may have assumed too much in this comment, but if this resonates i hope it will guide you. Alnarra you should be aware that that is bullshit. Where a video 6 months ago with 100,000 views would generate $100, it is now generating $10, if you're lucky. That also if your video is monetized. Most of Phil's videos are no longer monetized because of the strict policies on youtube now in regards to what is considered advertiser friendly. Most of his videos are now only available in unrestricted mode and that means they aren't able to be monetized. On top of that, he isn't just 1 guy sitting in a room, filming a video, editing it and uploading it. He has a whole team of people he employs that help him find content to talk about, research the stuff, write his "scripts" and i use that term lightly, edit his videos, do his graphics, handle his hr department, handle his accounting department and so on and so forth. He runs a traditional business and employs the amount of people it would take to run a traditional business. So even if he was making around $400k a year, after you take out youtubes cut, which is typically 40%, whoever his network was, again normally 30-40%, the taxes he then pays on that income, again 30%, then his employees pay, he is pretty much left with a normal salary for someone working at a fast food restaurant full time. But again, that's going off the old analytics which no longer apply to Phil or any other youtuber.

Alnarra People need to also remember that his channel is worth 3 mil. and he paid his way out of that contract. That couldn't have been cheap, and he paid that with his own money. Can't say I have seen him as much of him as most of you, but enough to say this. He seems to suffer from a bias. A neutrality bias. The news is supposed to be objective, not neutral.  Maybe now that he is on his own, that will end.   The last thing the world needs in another cable style chanel, presenting both sides of an issue where there is not 2 sides. An example being climate change, there is not 2 sides. Having 2 people on, one spouts political talking points, the other facts and calling it a draw, then saying what do you think folks!  I am only using climate change as an example. There are many sides to that debate about solutions, should we tax carbon, should we intervene in the climate etc...  We also don't need another chanel calling itself news, when all they do is repeat the reporting of actual news stations and giving their opinion. That is not news, we have TYT who does that and calls themselves independent media. They are neither independent nor media. Nothing wrong with that, but don't call yourself independent media.
Phil is in no way neutral. He always states his opinion as his opinion, but in that, he doesn't shut down the alternative.

No, he doesn't have to show you anything. I think you're the rude one for even asking this.

This kind of thinking is flawed from a logical standpoint. Let's say, for example, you have a grocery store in your neighborhood that you frequent for food and supplies every month. Do they have to post to you what they are paying the owner and/or employees? Do they have to inform the neighborhood of what they are spending their profits on? Does the owner of the store have to even publicly state what he's worth or how much he makes from the store each year? The answer to all of these is "No, they don't."   "But I'm giving him money VOLUNTARILY. I should have some kind of report of their income." No, you are NOT a stockholder, you are a Patron, which carries with it unique advantages and disadvantages. You are not buying into a share of their profits, therefore, you are not entitled to any financial disclosure on their part.  "But I want to know how much they're making to see if the content lives up to what I think X amount of money should buy." If you are afraid of paying someone before seeing or receiving the final product, simply don't. Let it ride a bit. There a plenty of people who will pledge early, and if you decide you like what they're doing, pledge later. If not, you can always contribute constructive feedback or just decide it's not for you.  No offense, of course. I've seen a lot of people say things like this lately. It seems some people think Patreon should have it's own kind of special social contract, but, to put it bluntly, I don't think it needs to be treated any differently than any other business where you pre-order specialty products.

CJ Krause, Actually, your thinking is the only thing that's flawed here. First off, you added levels to the "issue" that were completely non-existent in my original comment, and thus completely irrelevant. You painted a false equivalence between a fan-funded, online entertainment endeavour, and a standard business structure, which obviously has completely different cash flows and income sources. I mean, the grocery store is not funded by passionate customers. The store simply buys and sells items with a profit margin, whereas Phil creates virtually free content with an option to fund the production on the back end. These are not equivalent ar all.   Secondly, you're talking about this as if I have already contributed, and that I claim to be unhappy with my return. This is obviously not the case, as I clearly stated. I simply refrain from contributing until the total amount is displayed on the page (as it is for the vast majority of Patreon pages).  Imagine a fund-raiser for a charity, after which the organizers¬†refuse to tell people how much money was raised. Seems a bit weird, don't you think?   Besides,¬†an added bonus of displaying all the numbers on the page, such as how many people have chosen a certain reward tier, is that people who just want to support Phil and "ride the bandwagon" can do so. For instance, if you have trouble figuring out which tier is most worth it, you can easily make a choice based on the displayed stats, showing you which ones are the most popular. That way, you can feel more confident that you actually get some good perks for the money. Otherwise, you might very well have a constant thought of "Am I one of just a few to actually choose this tier, instead of the one above or below?".

gustavlp you don't get to just create stipulations and make demands. You have two options: contribute based off of the information given to you, or don't.  Each tier shows you exactly what you get for the amount of money you contribute. That's transparency.   The perks you get for contributing is considered a "thank you" for donating and making the project possible. If you have to weigh your options to get the best bang for you buck for a donation to make a project possible, then maybe charity just isn't for you. And that's a really sad thought.

So, this is an interesting discussion. I understand your point of view, however, I do still disagree on some major points. If I may, I will take on your points as they appear in your response. Firstly, I do not believe I added any layers to this. Quite the opposite; I peeled it both down to the basics. The basics in this case being a business offers products (whether tangible or virtual) for monetary compensation.   I would also disagree that they have different income sources unless you are literally talking about taking people's money at a register as opposed to funding someone through a website. In both cases, you are paying before you receive the product, yes? Beyond that, I'm referring specifically to your comment regarding funding of his Patreon for his news network, thus still talking about paying for something before you receive it.   The last thing I would like to address in your first paragraph is your claim that Phil makes "virtually free content". Unless you are talking about free to the consumer, this is horribly wrong. Phil definitely has overhead, he has mentioned before about having to pay employees, bills, etc. for his show. I would argue that all of these mentioned points that you made are in fact, adding the levels you claim that I added to the "issue".  Going beyond that, I will say that if the vast majority of Patreon pages list that, that is fine. But that should in no way pressure other creators into doing the same. Some people may not be comfortable with that, and, in this case, Phil has stated this is a huge project. As others have stated - and should be common sense - trying to start a legitimate news network (whether on YouTube or elsewhere) is a huge and expensive endeavor, and posting the kind of money that would take might create unrealistic expectations in people's minds. I would add as well, that I have seen plenty of fully-funded Kickstarter projects that mentioned nothing about how much the people behind the project would be taking as compensation for their time, though they obviously would have to in order to have some income to merely survive, if nothing else. However, that is obviously anecdotal, and I digress.  To your point about charities, I would have to argue that is a true false equivalency - one is a business, the other is, obviously, a charity. They are governed by different laws, and vastly different rules regarding financial disclosure. So, yes, I would agree that a charity not disclosing how much it took in would not only be weird, but (at least in the US) pretty messed up.  To your last point: that is purely personal preference. I would be more than happy with them simply showing the percentage of people who donated in each tier (though I would make no demands that they do so). That way, you can still "ride the bandwagon" if you wish, but there is no burden or expectations created from any kind of financial disclosure. (Although, personally, I would wonder why you would donate to a certain tier just because everyone else is, but that's just my opinion.) I'm of the belief that if you are spending money on something, that you are already ok with what you are getting for that money.  Regardless of our differences of opinion, thank you for a well-argued and civil discussion. Quite the rarity on YouTube.

This is probably gonna be swallowed by the deluge of incoming comments, but let's do this.  I remember the first time I saw one of your videos. It was like, 2009. I was in my world history class, not being a productive student. I saw one of your hilariously clickbait-y titles and said fuck it. I proceeded to watch one of the cringiest, douchey videos I'd seen in a long time. I hated the content haha.  Fast forward to 2015. I was in the hospital for two months after a major incident. June, I was in critical condition, constant surgeries. July I was stable, and had just gone into the physical rehab wing. And I was a month out of date, so I went on to YouTube to catch up. I came across one of your videos, but didn't make the connection to the massive douchebag from 2009. I loved your content. I binged through about 3 month's worth of content in the span of two weeks.  I've admired your desire to bring true news- current goings on rather than (the occasional) sensationalism drawn onto arbitrary bullshit. I've always wanted a place void of culture. No lines drawn between, "Us and Them." Religion, gender, politics in general don't matter here. Let's have a serious, respectful discussion about something, even if we keep all our biases intact. Then we can walk away simply having heard the other side. It's an amazing community you've gathered, and I thank you for it.  I don't know how bleak or vibrant all the behind-the-scenes, businessy bullshit is going, but here's to the best throughout all of it.

Why oh why couldn't I afford the bajillion (sp?) dollar tier?!!  Joking aside, Phil, I have been a fan of your show for longer than I can remember now.  I know as a 36 year old married father of two, I probably don't fit within your average audience demographic, but you need to know that us "older folks" appreciate what you do for journalism.  Your ability to look at a story, set aside your own opinion, and state the facts in an objective and non-coercive way is something that has been missing from MSM news for a long time.  On top of that, I appreciate that you are not afraid to state your opinion once the facts are presented, and that you allow for others to respectfully disagree with you.  The entire concept of having a conversation that you so wholeheartedly subscribe to is one I wish so many more people would buy in to.  I don't know if you have ever seen the show "The Newsroom" (it was on HBO for three seasons in the early 2010's), but your ideologies and methods towards journalism are very similar to the main character's from that show. If you haven't seen it, I highly recommend it.  I applaud what you are attempting to do and absolutely support you in this endeavor.  Good luck and godspeed.

He hardly ever opens up a story with "These people did this dumb thing and this guy is a horrible person"  it's more like "So this story blew up, here's what happened, here's what both sides of the issue are saying online, here's my sentiment."  The way that he starts with the facts allows you to decide before even hearing his opinion on what you think. I do think that some times Phil does get a bit too judgemental/simplify issues but the beauty of it is you're allowed to disagree.

I will be supporting you and I wish for you the utmost success.  To me, one of the challenges to your new venture is how to have this "conversation" you desire with your subscribers.  The commenting format of YouTube, Disqus, Facebook, or Twitter is not conducive to real conversations.  I don't have an answer, but I'd love to see a way to be able to comment on stories and read others' comments in some kind of non-linear fashion.  Top Comments or Newest First just don't cut it.  Maybe if the stories you share each have some type of commenting section of their own, rather than the entire show containing all the comments.  It's not feasible for viewers to wade through several thousand comments to know if a reply to a comment is more appropriate than making a new comment.  Sometimes, reading others' comments inspires me to see another point, but I can't read every comment, so I miss the majority of them, especially if I watch the video later than most, and if I watch the video shortly after it's released, I rarely go back to the video later to read comments. I hope you will be able to find a way to really engage your viewers through their interaction with you and each other.

I agree, but my only concern is that this idea might be too romanticised.  Even if we are to assume that Phil himself can present the facts in an objective way before getting opinions involved consistently (which he has done well so far) if more and more people are added to the team that may run the risk of the 'facts' getting slightly distorted, not researched properly, or subtly getting injected with a bias unintentionally or otherwise.  I trust in Phil's vision and a news network that focuses on facts first sounds great, but there's a part of me that feels like it can't be done.  That even if it does do well at launch it will only be a matter of time until the the objectivity starts slipping.  And that's not a judgement I'm making on Phil or any potential people he may hire to his news team, I just feel like it's human nature to gravitate towards bias even when you are trying not to.  Then again, maybe I'm just cynical.

How about no views and just the facts? CNN and FOX are full of political pundits on both sides giving their views and it's a shit show that plays into the reality tv drama that people love consuming. It's part of the reason we're in this mess. How about we go back to the days when television news outlets didn't editorialize so god damned much. The last thing we need is to hear more talking points from Antifa or Neo-nazis. Our population is full of people that are more passionate than thoughtful and think as long as someone is speaking passionately they must be right. Let's not giving these groups any more air time than they already have.

Agreed Jurgen.  How "News" is gathered is tricky. How it is presented is harder. There is a limited number of "facts" you can present in a 90 second bit about any news topic. The fresh news googled from Fox, buzzfeed, CNN, Brietbart, ... Has restricted "facts" to begin with.  Take this story "Dog bites man" and you want to do 90 seconds on this news. Do you. Call the man for a 60 second interview. Call the Dog owner for a 60 second interview. If you only call one of them you are open to accusation of bias. What if the Dog Owner has 300 seconds of "facts" to tell about the incident, but the Man has 120 seconds of "facts." How can you avoid bias or accusation of bias when you need to "edit" each persons "facts" to fit into 90 seconds total.  What if the Man, or Dog owner won't do an interview? Then you only have one side of the story so it is bias. EDIT: Of course not equally covering the "Fire fighter rescues Cat" story and covering the "Dog bites man" story is bias.

A little bit of information about myself before I post my view. I have been doing online debate for nearly two decades and one thing that still gets to me is the preponderance of anecdotes argued as fact. Alternative facts are the norm now and argued as objective facts as opposed to the anecdotes that they are. I see alternative facts as a form of confirmation bias where only the evidence that backs a predetermined narrative is accepted, and evidence that does not support the predetermined narrative is summarily dismissed. Evidence should be objectively followed to a conclusion as opposed to starting from a conclusion and finding the evidence that supports the predetermined narrative. As of late I have literally been arguing that we need an objective source of news. I have been a viewer of your channel for a while now and am impressed by your objectivity. If you start a news network then you will have my backing and I will promote you to the best of my ability so long as you continue to be objective. Sadly my living of a fixed income makes financial support not possible. We need more objectivity to counter all the bias and if that is your goal, count me in and I will support you in any way that I can. Name is Robert by the way.

"Back in the late 1700s, however, doctors literally blew smoke up people‚Äôs rectums. Believe it or not, it was a general mainstream medical procedure used to, among many other things, resuscitate people who were otherwise presumed dead. In fact, it was such a commonly used resuscitation method for drowning victims particularly, that the equipment used in this procedure was hung alongside certain major waterways, such as along the River Thames (equipment courtesy of the Royal Humane Society). People frequenting waterways were expected to know the location of this equipment similar to modern times concerning the location of defibrillators." Alright DeFranco, here we go.  I've been following you long enough to not be proud about starting to watch you, those were some rough beginnings. You've grown into a guy that I'm totally ecstatic to tell people I watch.  I don't think anyone starts without the intentions you've enumerated. Everyone wants to be independent and fair. Do I think you will actually pull through on it? Maybe. If past experience means anything, there are topics where I think you really do present both sides fantastically, but some where you seem purposefully middling, afraid to talk about the pros to one side even if you talk about the pros to the other (which you always do) for fear of COMMUNITY backlash.  Because that's that special thing about you. You see the tides turning. It's easier to break away from corporations now that the community has the power. Patreon, merch, crowdfunding projects, they are all more stable and often better paying than Youtube ad revenue. But they're as dependent on your community as you've ever been on a corporation.  I'm saying, please don't separate with the corrupting powers that be only to fall prey to the emergent corrupting power of public favor. You're gonna take hits. You're gonna say things people won't like. You always mention that you're okay with this happening, but now you're quite literally putting your money where your mouth is.  But as I said, if there's any single creator that I think could do it, it's you.  Best of luck, my guy.

This will probably get buried, but I just wanted to say Phil is one of the realest YouTubers out there and he deserves our support. A few years back I was invited to a Titanfall event Phil attended in LA. At the time my channel was only around 10k subs. Compared to the other people at the event (Nadeshot, Tobuscus, H3CZ & many more) I was small. Most of the big creators there were not too interested in talking to me. But I started up a conversation with Phil on the bus to the event as I'd been watching the PDS for years. To my surprise Phil was even nicer in real life. He gave me a ton of tips for YouTube, answered any questions I had and really inspired me to keep growing my channel, beyond all of that he was just... super nice, like REALLY genuine and kind in person, a real gentleman. A few years later I'm at 85k subs and growing steadily. Phil if you're reading this, thank you for being such a genuinely nice human being and treating others with respect. You deserve your success and you're an inspiration to many. I will definitely be supporting you on Patreon.

Calling¬†a network¬†"DeFranco Elite" might be a mistake. Most of all, it¬†has the elitist ring to it, giving it a negative connotation from the start. Then you put your name at the front, which while not bad in itself, sounds narcissistic. While it's fine as a show name with you as the main star/host, and¬†many people put their names in their company names, it's usually done in a neutral manner ("Soandso's Shipping Company", "Turner Broadcasting System"). Imagine if CNN was called Turner Elite? How much more flack would they be getting nowadays when supporting the establishment with that name? Putting both together just compounds their effect.  Elite is also a strong word (like 'super', 'extra', etc.), and shouldn't be used¬†in¬†the name of the whole network. If I were to give the name "DeFranco Elite" to anything, it would be like a chat or Q&A with your patrons or something.  Other than that, good luck!

Looks like I'm putting my money where my mouth is. I have long touted the importance of subscription fees, and the necessity we create as consumers for businesses and media that represent us and our concerns. We want accessible media, accurate news headlines, investigative journalism that doesn't have an agenda, and well-written entertainment. But nobody is willing to pay for it. Be honest, like me, it stems from the laziness of knowing there are other sources that siphon off original content and deliver it to you for free, all while selling out to advertisers and private investors who care about their bottom line. It's the sheer convenience of free media that keeps people from subscribing to print sources, websites with monthly fees, or even donating one-time payments to publicly funded stations (like PBS).  I think that after 6 years of watching Phil's Youtube channel change and evolve that I'm prepared to pay in for a non-partisan news station. This is one of the few places I come to for daily headlines and the occasional BAMF of the Day, and I think that this is one of the simplest ways to get involved in a project that can instigate positive change in the news media landscape. I'd be proud to be a part of that.

Dear Phil.   I know you have an ocean of comments and so my single drop will likely be lost, but I do hope someone on your team reads this and presents it to you.   I have followed you for a long time, this account is much younger than yours but I assure you that I was watching your channel from the first year that you created it. At the time channels like Katers17 and communitychannel were huge, I saw you arrive and have watched ever since. I have always respected the balanced approach that you took to reporting, an approach that the mainstream media had abandoned long ago. You always seemed to go out of your way to put aside your bias, which is exactly what a decent journalist should do.   With all of that said, I think it is important to note that simply talking about a topic is not enough as the facts we have available are often filtered through official sources. What is needed for a new media platform is an open source approach to the sourcing of material. If you want facts then they must come from direct on the ground sources, rather than analyzing the sources which are presented to us from the mainstream media. I wish you the best of luck for your new platform. From what you have produced over the years I believe that you will indeed create a superior news source.   All the best to you sir.

Think it's great that DeFranco is doing this. I've gone through several phases with this channel, throughout the years. In the beginning it was honestly just an annoyance - all of those damn clickbaits :P . But recently (last two years or so), I've followed the channel more closely. I've personally been annoyed with many news sites and commentators - everything has their personal point of view coloring the story, sometimes glaringly so. However, I don't really see this within the channel. He makes it clear that what he say is his own opinion (even stating that it is just that: his opinion, not fact), and there's an actual attempt to be objective (and something I think he succeeds at). And most importantly: he gives you both sides of the story, and I actually think that his goal is to find out the truth - and this isn't just something he says, but something that has been apparant in every episode I've seen. I actually trust what he says - which is hard to do, because I'm extremely cynical... So yeah, this is actually great for journalism. An actual news site with some damn ideals!  Wish him the very best!

I hate when people say "let's hear both parts out". Some topics, one side is so ridiculous with their beliefs that putting them on the same level does a disservice. For instance: You shouldn't discuss climate change with Bill Nye, and someone who says "God is the answer to everything. He will keep us safe & climate change is false". By having a discussion with someone who is clearly wrong and completely irrational, you're propping up a fake narrative that a topic like this is up for an actual debate, when in reality it's settled science. It's like Bill Nye says: If you're going to discuss a topic such as climate change, you can have a "skeptic" on as an "expert" or someone to "debate", but then you should also have 33 others that disagree with them. Otherwise you're weighing them as equally valid opinions.

One thing Phil: I hope to God that when you say "let's see what both sides are saying" that you acknowledge that sometimes there aren't two sides and one side SHOULD NOT be listened to because of its existence active detriment to society.  I'm talking, as you might have guessed, about climate change. The media's determination to "see what both sides are saying" has led to a nonsense debate that has possibly put the world past the point of no return in terms of fixing damage done to the planet by man-made climate change and given a platform to people where there should have been none (and I say that as someone who advocates for free speech in almost all circumstances).  So please, for the love of God, let there be a conversation but DON'T fall into the neutrality "two-side" traps that have plagued mainstream media for decades. There aren't always two sides (sometimes there's only one, sometimes there are seven) and allowing debates to exist where they shouldn't is dangerous. Either way, best of luck with the new venture, I'm sure it will take off! Will be watching with hope!

Dima Vasilev "For the love of God, don't let opinions that contradict my own on to your show because I think I have the authority to decide who is and who isn't worthy listening to." There are always two sides of the conversation either you like it or not. On global warming, on politics, even on the topic if the fucking earth is flat. For someone who advocates for free speech in almost (of course there's an almost) all circumstances, you sure like the idea of not giving a platform to people with opinions that you disagree on. And the thing about it being "dangerous" is just utter bullshit, it's only dangerous in a way that you're going to have to listen to opinions you don't want to hear.

+Lim Stefanic So how about allowing people to carry on saying smoking doesn't cause cancer and presenting it as a credible second side to the discussion? Unless Phil's news show goes "well here are the two sides, but let me be absolutely clear, this second side is dumb as fuck, factually wrong and might make things worse if people hear it and believe it, but gotta have two sides, what you gonna do?" then it is an issue. If his show actively debunks the bullshit second side on air in real time and makes paid-off "experts" from pharmaceutical/oil/whichever companies have to disclose on-screen the money that backs their views and "evidence," then I'm all for it, let's pretend two sides all the way. But the likelihood of that being the case is unbelievably slim. EDIT: And by the by, I'm talking in the case of debunked, factless opinions not being given air time. People can air their opinions all they want, but when it's something the equivalent of "gravity isn't real" or "alcohol causes no health issues" and the person saying it isn't presented as dumb/lying/extremely-very-wrong, then that is the "almost" for me - a case where it is empirically wrong, there's no room for debate, and allowing other discussion drags society back when progress is essential. Just try and say letting people believe smoking is good for you isn't dangerous, go on? You wouldn't allow a kid who insisted "1+1=3" to repeatedly spout that view in a class which has already understood and is trying to move on, since that kid would get in the way of the other kids learning and making progress. You'd take the kid to one side and explain one-on-one why they're wrong and pray they got it eventually, but you wouldn't let them prevent the other kids from progressing. You don't drag everyone backwards for the sake of stupid.

Dima Vasilev Well yes, I'm all in for allowing people to carry on saying smoking doesn't cause cancer. It doesn't matter what you think makes things worse, if people believe it, if it's a big issue etc. Free speech isn't just some weird thing to fap around whenever you feel like it, it's a principal. And no matter how stupid, bad meaning etc. someone's views are, everyone, as a principal, should always have the liberty to express their views. I can see that based on your comments about "not letting people who deny man-made climate change to have a spot on the show because it's dangerous" you don't understand that free speech isn't just the freedom to express yourself, it's the freedom to make a fool out of yourself as well. Free speech is free speech, it's a principal that cannot be bent and cannot be broken. Even the most stupid views must be able to access the public forum so the public can savagely rip them to shreds.

+Lim Stefanic Like I said, I'd give those people a platform for those debunked, factually incorrect opinions, provided that as soon as they were given, they were immediately fact checked, debunked and had it made sufficiently clear that the person spouting that belief is a liar/paid off/thick as two short planks. I don't trust the average person to listen to a confident well-versed oil-paid politician talk about climate change not existing/not being man-made/etc. and remain completely unswayed. Family members of mine who are college educated are still swayed on the climate change nonsense because they don't find out that the charlatan onscreen is an oil lobbyist. Broadly speaking I think we agree on picking apart stupid views through debate, but the media have done a piss-poor job of making it sufficiently clear how backwards some views are or where they're coming from. Treating facts as opinions, to me, gets into a very dicey area of free speech - you can have opinions on the slant of those facts, but acting like they aren't facts is highly detrimental, and the news (a venue where you're meant to factually inform yourself) should not allow that to be possible. I want to trust Phil to be the news channel that will lead the way in debunking stupidity and exposing vested interests live, but "let's hear two sides" worries me based on the history of the news. I guess it comes down to "how much faith do you have in Phil and his team to do the right job in highlighting facts?"

I sometimes worry when you talk about these things. It sounds great the way you present it, but I see a lot of downsides to it. First, it seems like you are very prone to being bias. Not toward the left or the right, but the middle. Putting two people with differing opinions on each side of the table to debate each other is good if there's really a discussion to be had, but that also leads to a false equivalency in certain topics. Climate change deniers vs climatologists, conspiracy theorists vs scientists... If the overwhelming amount of evidence favors one side of an argument, then acting as if both sides have equal weight to their points does a massive disservice to the viewing public who will think there is no truth to get to, it's all just opinions. Second, you talk about mainstream media the same way a lot of people talk about experts in any given field with a certain amount of distrust or downright disdain for them. The WSJ has published some silly shit in the past that were clear mistakes, same with Rolling Stone, Time, and any other outlet that employs actual journalists, but that doesn't mean you can't trust anything they say. I know you need to try to brand yourself as being different from the sources because they have such a stink on them right now (at least as perceived by other people), but just try to keep that in mind when you actually start your network. Please hire real journalists to vet the news.

That's a great way to think about news, but as someone often (not always) on the opposite end of your views and values, especially concerning politics, I feel like I should say you can be very condescending when discussing people who don't share your side. "Facts" are only facts if they're as unbiased as possible. Change up your sources, since there are so many that don't fall under that category nowadays. If you find something, always see if there's something that says otherwise. Don't ever take "facts" as facts just because someone says that's what they are. If you're serious about trying to be focused on actual, unbiased facts, power to you. If not, you'll just be like all of the other extreme viewpoints on both sides, never taking the other fully into account.
